Did you know that Canada categorizes road salt as an environmental toxin harmful to plants, animals and the aquatic environment? Here are a couple of alternatives: Environmentally safe de-icing liquid: Mix equal amounts of vinegar and water to produce an effective de-icer. If the ice is very thick, combine 40 percent water and 60 percent vinegar. Pour the mixture on iced surfaces, and the ice slowly turns into liquid. Or use two parts rubbing alcohol to one part water. Then add one teaspoon of liquid dish soap. Either of these can be used on windows and door locks.

Did you know that Canada categorizes road salt as an environmental toxin harmful to plants, animals and the aquatic environment? Here are a couple of alternatives: Environmentally safe de-icing liquid: Mix equal amounts of vinegar and water to produce an effective de-icer. If the ice is very thick combine 40 percent water and 60 percent vinegar. Pour the mixture on iced surfaces, and ice slowly turns into liquid. Or use two parts rubbing alcohol to one part water. Then add a teaspoon of liquid dish soap. Either of these can be used on windows as well as door locks, too.

Congratulations to Dr. Glen Harris, recipient of OCA’s Research and Academic Award. The award recognizes a chiropractor or researcher engaged in research or academia contributing to expanding the knowledge of the profession. Among his many professional attributes, Dr. Harris has been supporting and mentoring his students for decades as a clinician. He has been part of CMCC’s Research Ethics Board for many years and is currently assisting with assessments and research into persistent pain at the Schroeder Pain Assessment and Rehabilitation Research Centre, part of UHN and sat on the OCA’s Evidence-Based Framework Advisory Council (EBFAC). Because of his work and commitment to education, chiropractors across Canada have improved their practices and quality of care. Dr. Harris is shown below with OCA Board Member Dr. Keshina Malik, who presented the award.

CMCC is proud to congratulate Dr. Tony Tibbles, Dean, Clinics, named OCA’s Chiropractor of the Year. The Chiropractor of the Year is OCA’s most prestigious award. It is given to a practicing chiropractor to recognize their outstanding service, professional achievement, and significant contribution, which influences and benefits the profession. The recipient demonstrates the qualities of a leader who upholds the highest professional and ethical standards in their practice. #COTY23

HELLO ?! IS ANYBODY THERE ????? By now many of you may have heard the news about Meta and Bill C-18. Meta, the parent company of Facebook and Instagram, has made the decision to block all news sources in Canada on its platforms. Unfortunately, that also includes non-profit radio, aka your favorite campus radio station CiTR101.9FM (at least we hope your fave is us ??) If you're able to see this post please share a screenshot of the post to your story !! ???? Why is this happening? This is the result of a battle between the Canadian government and tech giants Meta & Google over the Online News Act (Bill C-18). The bill was passed back in June and required digital companies to share revenue with Canadian news organizations by paying them anytime someone reached a webstory through a link on their platforms. Meta has recently fired back by saying it will just block Canadian news off its platforms. Not-For-Profit Radio was included in the bill and according to the National Campus & Community Radio Association (NCRA), Meta has refused to meet with Campus/Community Radio associations. For more information on the situation and how it affects campus radio, please head to the NCRA’s website. (https://ncra.ca/banned/) So what’s our plan? Firstly, we urge everyone to follow us on Twitter (@CiTRradio) and join our Discord server (https://discord.com/invite/pfTxfnAy2G). Our Discord server allows communication between members and different departments, and we also post any announcements. Secondly, we are hoping to post updates about CiTR & Discorder and our events on the Fanta Records Instagram page (our Record Label). Please follow @fantarecords for more updates and fingers crossed the page stays up. We are going to be experimenting and seeing what kind of content we can keep posting without being flagged. As we have our Victory Square Block Party event coming up (Sept. 3rd) and Shindig coming up in the fall, we will continue to post our event promo and updates on that account. We will try and keep everyone updated on the situation as we figure things out. In the meantime, stay tuned and stay reading with CiTR & Discorder. We love you all! mWAH! ??

The 2nd @queerfilmfest film we're sponsoring is a collection of short films entitled, "Shorts: Inner Riots" ????? The in-person screening is Sunday August 13th at 2PM at the International Village - Theatre 8 ???? Also available for viewing online Aug. 14-17 ???? The shorts in order as pictured: The Spirit God Gave Us - ?? dir. Michael Donte Jemison "Sitting at the intersections of love and faith, Blackness and Queerness, Malcolm and Shamont wrestle with shame, religious piety, and deep longing." Butch Up! - ?? dir. Yu-Jin Lee "Underappreciated by her straight indie band, Mi-hae finds community after meeting trans artist Coco (Hae-jun Choi)." GORDITX - ?? dir. Malik Ever "Ursula doesn’t fit in at the country club where her dad works. Trans masc Chef Cormac doesn’t either. Together they hatch a plan to win the kids’ golf tournament." Twin Sparks - ??dir. Ollie Yao & Heather Yun "When a forest child’s inner fire spirit breaks loose, they frantically try to catch it before damage is done. Inspired by co-director Ollie Yao’s experience growing up trans, this is a beautiful tale of radical self-acceptance." Foreign Uncle - ?? dir. Sining Xiang "Featuring re-enactments from his own family, director Sining Xiang relives the experience of introducing his white American boyfriend to his Chinese family, who are oblivious to their gay relationship." ______________________________________________ The Vancouver Queer Film Festival is back for its 35th anniversary ???? An AI-powered revolution in clean energy chemistry Ada, the first self-driving lab to fast-track clean energy materials, has come of age. With the signing of the Paris Climate Accord, most of the world’s governments agreed that we’d need to slash fossil fuel emissions in half to reach net zero by 2050. Net zero is the point of equilibrium between the greenhouse gas we produce and what’s removed from the atmosphere by forest and ocean carbon sinks. Clean energy technologies such as solar panels, improved batteries and fuel cells offered hope in reducing emissions, but the Paris Agreement made clear that there was massive gap in getting affordable new products to market. Materials discovery is a major part of the innovation cycle of clean energy technology, but developing commercially viable materials typically takes over a decade. That technological shortfall sparked Mission Innovation, a global initiative launched in 2017 to find ways to break the research and development bottleneck. Mission Innovation issued a call to action — combine materials science with automation and artificial intelligence to accelerate materials discovery by at least ten-fold. Canada was the first to answer this call with the launch of Project Ada, a University of British Columbia-led initiative that positioned the nation as a world leader in self-driving labs. In 2018, an $8 million Natural Resources Canada grant enabled UBC professors Dr. Curtis Berlinguette and Dr. Jason Hein, along with Dr. Alán Aspuru-Guzik of the University of Toronto, to assemble “Ada”, the first self-driving lab for clean energy materials. The multidisciplinary team chose the name in honour of Ada Lovelace, the world’s first computer programmer. Self-driving labs like Ada think for and work by themselves, combining automation with machine learning to plan, conduct and analyze experiments much faster than humans can. @cpb_cleanenergy @ubcchem @mirusmarttech #selfdrivinglabs #AI #robotics #chemistry #cleanenergy See Linktree in our bio to learn more or go to bit.ly/ai-chem-lab

How hummingbirds switch gears at breakneck speeds Hummingbirds are some of the fastest and most agile birds on Earth. They can squeeze into incredibly small spaces to get nectar and hit flight speeds as high as 9Gs while courting without getting physically hurt. They also appear to have very controlled methods of flight. Hummingbirds use two distinct sensory strategies to control how they fly, depending on whether they are moving forward or hovering. The findings are described in a study published January 10 in the journal Proceedings of the Royal Society B. When flying forward, hummingbirds rely on an “internal forward model.” This model is an ingrained and intuitive autopilot that allows them to gauge speed while experiencing multiple visual stimuli. “There’s just too much information coming in to rely directly on every visual cue from your surroundings,” study co-author and @ZoologyUBC prof Dr. Vikram B. Baliga said. However, when the birds are hovering or handling cues that may require them to change their altitude, the team found that they use more real-time, direct visuals from their environment. To study these flight patterns, the team brought 11 wild adult male Anna’s hummingbirds (Calypte anna) into the lab. They prompted the birds to repeatedly fly from a perch to a feeder in a tunnel about 13 feet long and recorded videos of each flight. The team also projected patterns on the front and side walls of the tunnel to test how the hummingbirds reacted to this variety of visual stimuli. “If the birds were taking their cues directly from visual stimuli, we’d expect them to adjust their forward velocity to the speed of vertical stripes on the side walls,” said Baliga. “But while the birds did change velocity or stop altogether depending on the patterns, there wasn’t a neat correlation.” The findings provide insight on how these speedy birds perceive the world when they transition their flight patterns. Data like this could also help engineers develop better onboard navigation systems for drones and hovering vehicles in the future.

An all-woman crew of marine scientists is rowing 5,000 km non-stop across the Atlantic Ocean to raise $500K for ocean conservation. The Salty Science crew @saltysciencerowing is taking part in the @worlds.toughest.row where teams race without stopping and without support from the Canary Islands to Antigua. UBC Institute for the Oceans and Fisheries grad student Lauren Shea is one of the crew members who will set out on Dec. 13, weather permitting. The voyage will take anywhere from 40 to 55 days.

New @ubcstatistics prof Dr. Geoff Pleiss brings stats and #computerscience together to improve the accessibility and reliability of #AI. His research opens new avenues for different ways of making data-driven discoveries.

Congratulations to Dr. Mark Van Raamsdonk of @ubcphas who has been named a Fellow of The Royal Society of Canada. His research is designed to build a better theoretical understanding of elementary particle #physics, classical and #quantum gravity, and #cosmology. He is currently working to understand the implications for gravitational physics of fundamental results in quantum information theory, and also to understand better which properties of quantum states are required to describe gravitational space-times.

Congratulations to Dr. Leah Edelstein-Keshet of @ubcmath on her election to the Royal Society of Canada. RSC Fellows are distinguished Canadians who have made remarkable contributions in the arts, the humanities and the sciences, as well as in Canadian public life.

Visual AI: The cat is out of the bag. Computer scientist Dr. Kwang Moo Yi of @ubc_cp_sc teamed up with @Adobe and @apple to reconstruct 3D images and videos from situations that never existed. Since #deeplearning was introduced to computer vision in 2012, its capabilities have grown in leaps and bounds. #AI now allows for the reconstruction of #3D images and videos from situations that never existed. The photo-realistic rendering is important for augmented reality experiences, but it also raises the threat of deep fake videos at a time when politics are already polarized and disinformation rampant. “How do you know what you’re seeing is real? What’s the credibility of a video?” asks Dr. Yi. “So there are societal implications now, because the technology is working so well. And it’s very close to being available more broadly.” #VisualAI #GraphicDesign #VideoEditing See Linktree in our bio to learn more.

How do you find out how new species form during a pandemic lockdown? Dr. Katie Marshall of @ZoologyUBC turned to crowd-sourced science. Humans have an immense effect on our planet’s ecosystems, and new species may be forming just as quickly as they disappear. So, to understand processes driving biodiversity on Earth, we need to understand how those processes impact the creatures that make up much of that biodiversity. See Linktree in our bio to learn more ...

Today Dr. Kayla King was appointed Canada Excellence Research Chair in Evolutionary Dynamics of Host-Pathogen Interactions. She recently joined @ubcmbim & @ZoologyUBC where her research aims to better understand the evolution of infection and immunity in a changing world.

Fire Across the Land: Truth and Reconciliation Workshops for UBC Science students, staff & faculty. Hosted by @ubcgarden Deepen your understanding of First Nations history in Canada. Thurs Nov 2 9:30-12:30 FREE registration: bit.ly/fire-land UBC Botanical Garden is pleased to host workshops this year to support Truth and Reconciliation training for students, staff and faculty in the Faculty of Science. The sessions are a reprisal of workshops held last year – offering the UBC Science community ongoing opportunities to learn, engage and ultimately help advance the important work of Reconciliation Join us in person for a three-hour workshop to deepen your understanding of First Nations history in Canada. The goal of this project is to increase the collective capacity of UBC Science to understand the lived experiences of Indigenous Peoples as well as to learn about colonial Canadian narratives that impact Indigenous communities. Instructor Brad Marsden (@bradmarsden7) from the Gitksan Nation, British Columbia, creates space for groups to learn, listen, understand and discuss the impact of residential schools and colonization. This workshop is supported by the UBC Science Strategic Innovation Fund to help advance the UBC Indigenous Strategic Plan. @fireacrosstheland_workshop

Orthotics are custom-made insole devices designed to provide arch support, cushioning, and alignment correction for specific foot-related issues. These orthotics are crafted based on a detailed assessment of the foot structure, gait, and any other existing foot conditions.   Our new technology utilizes a digital scan of the feet and design software to scientifically assess the foot structure and create the customized prescription orthotic. The digital orthotic design is precisely milled from the selected insole material using a computerized milling machine. To get started and book your appointment, click the link in our bio or at https://couvehealth.janeapp.com/#/staff_member/47 For more information: ?? Call us at (604) 449 -7606 ??
